item.title: Which Houses Sell Fast in Our Current Market?
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
I‚Äôve been talking about the importance of pricing for years. The market has changed a little bit, though, and buyers aren‚Äôt as concerned about price as they are about condition. Even if you‚Äôre priced correctly for your home‚Äôs condition, it‚Äôs a tough sale if there‚Äôs a lot of work that needs to be done.
When buyers go online, they won‚Äôt like homes that don‚Äôt look ready to go. They won‚Äôt see the house in person if there isn‚Äôt some emotional connection. If they do walk into your house and it has a lot of obvious deferred maintenance, it‚Äôs going to be a tough sell.
‚ÄúHomes that aren‚Äôt in good condition may not sell at all.‚Äù
If you‚Äôre maybe a year or two out from selling, it‚Äôs time for you to take care of that deferred maintenance now. Your roof, windows, HVAC system, etc., should all be checked and in proper working order. Your house needs to be in good condition to sell in this market.
A buyer I worked with recently found a home that was on the market and in great condition. They loved that the roof was new, the mechanicals were in good working order, and the kitchen was fresh and updated with appliances. Everything in the house had been taken care of, so it was an easy sell. There was nothing left in the house that needed to be ‚Äútaken care of.‚Äù The only thing that the buyers needed to do was customize it to their liking. item.title: A Market Update & an Ugly Tax Reality
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
Instead of hammering you with stats, today I‚Äôll offer a market update for the North Shore of Chicago based on my boots-on-the-ground experience. Generally speaking, it still holds that if a house is in good condition and priced correctly, it will definitely sell. But what‚Äôs the mood? What am I hearing day in and day out?¬†
Taxes are a really big issue right now. Buyers nowadays are much smarter than they used to be it seems; they‚Äôre very aware that property taxes will continue to skyrocket here in Illinois. When they‚Äôre looking at houses, they‚Äôre factoring in taxes first. A lot of high-tax houses are sitting, and will likely continue to sit. Sellers, there‚Äôs not much you can do about this, other than cut your price.¬†
In my opinion, it‚Äôs ridiculous that elected officials in our state can‚Äôt grasp the gravity of the situation unfolding. Let me make this clear: This isn‚Äôt intended to be a political commentary to sway Illinois voters one way or another; I‚Äôm just stating that if you keep raising property taxes in a state, people will eventually start leaving in droves, which, in turn, will decrease home values.¬†
I had a buyer recently find a home to their liking way outside of the city for $250,000. The problem, however, was that the taxes on this property were $13,000. This blew their whole budget, and they had to pass on the home. Sadly, I just feel like the issue of exorbitant property taxes isn‚Äôt being addressed by our representatives.¬†
‚ÄúBuyers in our market are availing themselves of all of the data available online these days.‚Äù
You must appeal your taxes every year. If you need help with this, just let me know, as I can connect you with a trusted professional. If you know you‚Äôll be selling and your taxes are high, you may want to give yourself a longer listing time to account for the fact that not as many buyers will be able to afford that aspect of your home.¬†
Buyers in our market are availing themselves of all of the data available online these days, and, on average, are waiting a little longer to buy.¬†
My overall feel of the North Shore market: Things are selling but you have to make the necessary upgrades and do things right‚Äîcross your t‚Äôs and dot your i‚Äôs. item.title: Downsizing the Right Way
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
If you‚Äôre over the age of 50, you‚Äôll probably want to start thinking about downsizing. Perhaps your kids are grown up and off to college, and it‚Äôs time to think about the next stage in your life.¬†
Downsizing is a topic I discuss with people all the time, and the first thing you need to know is where you‚Äôll go. I‚Äôd say that three out of every five sellers I currently work with are moving out of state or renting, and one of the reasons why is they can‚Äôt find the housing they‚Äôre looking for. There aren‚Äôt a lot of great downsizing options on the North Shore. This is why you have to start looking for homes early and know what you‚Äôre looking for.¬†
For example, there aren‚Äôt a lot of large ranches in maintenance-free communities because they take up a lot of space. If you do find one of these properties in a maintenance-free community, it will be very expensive. When it comes to downsizing, something usually has to give in terms of what you want in a home.¬†
‚ÄúMillennials want homes to look move-in ready.‚Äù
Next, think about how you‚Äôll sell your home. Millennial buyers are different than the buyers that were around when I bought my home. They look at things differently, and their priorities are not your priorities. You have to consider the fact that you‚Äôll have to target your house to a whole new market and understand that demographic.¬†
By and large, millennials want homes to look move-in ready. They‚Äôre not willing to take on many projects; they‚Äôd rather have everything updated. This is why, no matter what your downsizing timeline is, you need to talk to an agent sooner rather than later so that you understand your new target market. Where should you spend your money (and where shouldn‚Äôt you)?¬†
If you‚Äôre serious about downsizing the right way, I‚Äôm hosting a seminar that will cover this topic in-depth on January 29 at my office. Sellers who‚Äôve attended my previous seminars found it very informative because I offer all of my insight, whether you hire me as your agent or not. At this seminar, I‚Äôll go over the downsizing process step by step, so if you‚Äôre, say, five years away from actually downsizing, I highly recommend attending. Space is limited, so use this link to register now and find out the rest of the details. ¬†
If you can‚Äôt make it but you have more questions about this topic, feel free to call or email me. I‚Äôd love to speak with you.

item.title: Why Should You Not Hire Me?
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
Today I am going to answer the question, ‚ÄúWhy should you not hire me as your real estate agent?‚Äù
Truly, it‚Äôs if you don‚Äôt want the genuine truth. I am honest with my clients. I‚Äôm pretty blunt and frank. I‚Äôm going to present it to you the way that I see it. I try to make it a bit softer, but I don‚Äôt want my clients to be in a position where a year or two after they‚Äôve listed their house, they‚Äôre still on the market. I will be 100% honest with you even if you don‚Äôt like the answer.
Here is a real-life example. I was in a situation about a year and a half ago where I went to give a price estimate and the homeowners were interviewing three agents. I gave them a price of $649,000, but if they needed to sell immediately, I said $599,000. I was not chosen, they went with the agent that priced it at $769,000, which was way too high for the market. However, the other agent said, ‚ÄúYeah, we‚Äôll do it, we can get that.‚Äù¬†
Then, after six months that listing expired and they thought it was the agent‚Äôs fault when it wasn‚Äôt. Then they went with an agent that reduced it to $699,000. After that, it had to be reduced to $639,000, then $629,000, and finally, they decreased to $599,000, the price I had given them, 14 months later. Now, they still have not closed after 16 months on the market. So, they had carrying costs, time aggravation, and showing irritations.¬†
‚ÄúI will be 100% honest with you even if you don‚Äôt like the answer.‚Äù
Showing your house can be an agonizing experience and having showings and being ready for showings every day is arduous. Imagine being on the market for 16 months! Maybe they simply didn‚Äôt like me, but the point is that they didn‚Äôt listen to what I was saying as being valid. It‚Äôs fine to do that, but it ended up costing them time and money.¬†
Work with an agent who you can trust and who knows the market. I do not want people to overspend on improvements on their home. I want people to sell their houses and sell quickly. To that end, our clients can cancel their listing agreement with us at any time because if they feel we are not being forthright, we want them to feel that they can leave. This allows us to have an improved conversation with our clients about the market. We‚Äôre telling you the truth about what will get your house sold. It‚Äôs up to you now to decide where you want to go with that.
If you have any questions, want to chat, or you want an estimate on your home with no obligation, feel free to reach out. The easiest way is to email me but I‚Äôm also available by phone or text as well. I look forward to hearing from you!

item.title: Selling in the Fall Market vs. the Spring
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
All the time, people lament to me that because they missed the spring market, they might as well not put their house on the market until next year.
That is totally wrong, and today I‚Äôll explain why.
People buy and sell homes all year long; it‚Äôs not like nobody buys or sells in the fall and winter! Mind you, the market is seasonal and tends to slow down, so while there aren‚Äôt as many people looking for houses, there‚Äôs also not as much inventory‚Äîthat means less competition for you.
When you have one of the only two Colonial homes in your school district, for example, and a buyer has to move soon, that means yours is one of the two homes that that buyer will choose from.
If you want to sell your house, you have to list it. Don‚Äôt try to be super strategic about it in terms of timing. Remember, when you list in the springtime, you‚Äôll be competing with a lot of fresh inventory, as well, and especially if you plan you test the price of your home.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre looking for a May, June, or July closing, I strongly recommend having your home on the market by the second week of January.‚Äù
Last year, I had five homes that sold in just the first week of January, and they had been on the market since August. So if you have a home on the market and you‚Äôre thinking of taking it off the market, don‚Äôt. Leave it on. If you don‚Äôt want to do showings during the holidays, then you don‚Äôt have to. Just cancel the showing; your agent can still collect the information from the buyer‚Äôs agent who tried to schedule the listing and then schedule a follow-up when your time is freer. If your house is totally off the market, then you won‚Äôt get any showings at all and you won‚Äôt sell your home.
You might have decided that the spring market is best for you because, for example, you don‚Äôt plan to close until June or July, so you‚Äôre just going to wait until after the Superbowl. Keep this in mind: It‚Äôs cold after the Superbowl! I don‚Äôt really abide by that strategy because you‚Äôll still have to compete with all the other fresh inventory. Plus, if you list your home in March or April and you either miss the first rush or you‚Äôve overpriced your home, you‚Äôll only ride the market down until you have to start doing price reductions.
That‚Äôs why I prefer to list my houses earlier in the year, rather than later. If you‚Äôre looking for a May, June, or July closing, I strongly recommend having your home on the market by the second week of January. In case you end up selling your home before your initial plan, I‚Äôll make sure to ask if you have temporary housing or someplace to go before you list‚Äîif you don‚Äôt, that would be a situation where it might be better to list a bit later in the year. However, the price may have to be a bit lower if you want an offer right away.
In the end, I always say it‚Äôs better to list your house when you‚Äôre ready to move; if you need to move now, then list your house now. There are always people looking for homes, even if certain times of the year are slower than others. But at least you‚Äôll have the chance to sell‚Äîif you don‚Äôt list your home, then you are definitely not going to sell anything.
If you have any questions about buying or selling homes in the fall and spring months, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to me. I‚Äôd be glad to help you.

We‚Äôre more than halfway through 2019, which means now is the perfect time for another update on our North Shore real estate market. We‚Äôll cover all the relevant trends buyers, sellers, and homeowners in our area should know.
For a more in-depth look at these trends, be sure to follow along in today‚Äôs video or check out our market reports below.¬†
Let‚Äôs start by looking at median sales prices over the past decade. In 2009, when our market was just beginning to decline, the median sales price in our North Shore market was $575,000. Now, the median sales price in our area is $525,000. The average sales price for July 2019, meanwhile, was $631,835.¬†
‚ÄúNow that our market has recovered, inventory has increased as a result.‚Äù
But what about the number of homes for sale?
In January of 2009, there were 3,523 homes available in our North Shore market. When our market hit bottom in 2014, the number of available properties was cut in half, with just above 1,500 properties listed at that time. Now that our market has recovered, inventory has increased as a result. We had 2,266 available properties on our North Shore Market this July. Put another way, we had approximately 17 months‚Äô worth of supply in 2009, but just 6.8 months‚Äô worth this July.¬†
And because of the comparatively low levels of supply we‚Äôre now seeing, the average amount of time homes are spending on the market has also dropped. As of this July, the average days on market in the North Shore was 119. Homes still aren‚Äôt selling as quickly as they do in other markets, but this is a significant drop from the 213-day average we saw in late 2009.¬†
In other positive news, the number of closed homes has also increased in the last decade. In January of 2009, just 2,240 homes sold. This July, that number nearly doubled, with 3,934 homes closing that month.¬†
Homes have also become more affordable over that period. Between March of 2009 and July of 2019, the median price per square foot in our market has dropped from $242 to $216.¬†
And given the high number of new listings hitting our market, with 9,164 new properties going live this July, home prices are likely to drop even further.¬†
Of course, all of the figures we‚Äôve discussed today only give a general overview of our North Shore real estate market. item.title: How Can A Seller Tell a Good Offer From One That Isn‚Äôt?
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
Since going on the market, your home has been on the receiving end of multiple offers. How will you know which offer to take in this scenario? A better question might even be: How can I discern a strong offer from those that aren‚Äôt?¬†
Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve set your price at $200,000 and a buyer comes in offering $225,000. At face value, this seems like a strong offer that you shouldn‚Äôt pass up. The reality is that buyers can sometimes let their emotions get in the way of sound judgment; they might throw out an offer and not realize that they‚Äôre probably overpaying until you‚Äôve gone under contract. Consequently, they decide to withdraw their offer. ¬†
By this point, you may have already made the mistake of accepting an offer like this with a few different buyers. Really, the highest priced offer isn‚Äôt always the best offer. The best offer, then, is the one that‚Äôs actually going to close. ¬†
This is where your agent comes in: They should be able to pick up on clues during the showings, the offer process, negotiations, and inspection. A professional, experienced agent will be adept at reading the buyer.
‚ÄúThe best offer is the one that‚Äôs actually going to close.‚Äù
Now, if the offer price is too high, it probably won‚Äôt appraise, which means the buyer will not be able to obtain a mortgage. One of three things will happen at that point: They‚Äôll have to come up with additional money, you‚Äôll have to go lower in price (which usually happens), or you‚Äôll have to reenter the market; all three of these options are less than ideal.¬†
A cash offer way above asking price, on the other hand, can be good because you won‚Äôt need to bring in an appraiser; you‚Äôll want to know if this is in the contract or not.¬†
As a seller, try not to be enticed by an offer that‚Äôs a few thousand dollars higher; a good offer with the highest probability of closing should take priority. Once you‚Äôve made up your mind to take an offer and you‚Äôve gotten through attorney review, the emotional fatigue will give you eagerness to close.¬†
What if a buyer includes a mortgage contingency in their offer? If this is the case, keep in mind that the buyer will have that contingency all the way up until closing. This means there will be some uncertainty until the day comes. ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†¬†
Between an offer that‚Äôs $200,000 in cash and another that‚Äôs $225,000 with a mortgage contingency, you should strongly consider taking the cash offer because you can be sure that the deal will close.¬†
Another thing to look for in an offer is the behavior of the buyer. Plainly put, you want to work with an ‚Äúeasy‚Äù buyer. What do I mean by that? Well, some seller clients and I recently worked with a buyer who had been to the home three or four times and was hung up on one item, in particular.¬†
They asked about the item to no end, and it completely turned my sellers off. When it came time to select an offer, my seller didn‚Äôt even consider this buyer‚Äôs because of how difficult they had been. This is the type of buyer you‚Äôd do well to avoid.¬†
I hope today‚Äôs message helped you better understand what kind of offer you should look for. If you have any questions about this or about anything else real estate-related, feel free to reach out to me. I look forward to hearing from you!

item.title: A Guide for First-Time Homebuyers
item.author: Kati Spaniak

If you‚Äôre a first-time homebuyer, how do you go about finding a home? Here are a few tips that will help ease you into the process and make sure you get to the closing table with as little hassle as possible.¬†
First, start looking around online and researching local agents in the area. Some of the bigger real estate sites like Zillow might not be updated all the time, so it‚Äôs a good idea to connect with some local agents early on.
After that, tour the areas you want to live in and narrow them down. During this time, you‚Äôll also want to start interviewing agents. I know a lot of millennials nowadays insist that they can buy a home on their own, and maybe that‚Äôs true, but agents can provide you with a lot of information you otherwise won‚Äôt have.¬†
For example, they can help advise you on what you‚Äôre looking for and steer you in the right direction so you don‚Äôt waste your time looking at houses that aren‚Äôt a good fit. After all, they‚Äôve very likely been in many of the houses in the area you‚Äôre looking to live in.¬†
On a related note, remember that a home‚Äôs online pictures don‚Äôt always tell the whole story. A lot of people don‚Äôt want to waste their time looking at homes that don‚Äôt look great in pictures, but you can‚Äôt count on these pictures to tell you exactly how a house looks or whether it‚Äôs really in an area you want to live in. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to see them in person. Once in a while, you might get a lowball offer, but serious buyers typically don‚Äôt throw out lowball offers because, with all the information that‚Äôs available online, they‚Äôll know what your home should be priced at.¬†
In any case, you don‚Äôt want to wait for a lowball offer, because that buyer will be in the driver‚Äôs seat during negotiations. To avoid overpricing your home, look at it through the eyes of a buyer. Look at all the comparable properties in your neighborhood and be objective. Remember, your home is only worth what a buyer will pay for it.¬†
The second mistake is not countering an initial offer. Some buyers get emotional over an offer that they think is too low and then decide not to counter it. item.title: Don‚Äôt Let the Home Inspection Get Out of Control
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
How do home inspections get out of control? I‚Äôll examine this question from both the buyer‚Äôs and seller‚Äôs perspective.
First, an inspection is done after a contract has been accepted and agreed upon by both parties. The inspection usually occurs within the first five to seven business days. The inspection is there to see if there are any major issues with the house.
This is where a lot of people get hung up. A major issue would be something like water in the basement, a leaky roof, or mold in the attic. Major issues do not include things like a drawer that doesn‚Äôt shut. If a handyman can fix it, it‚Äôs probably not a major issue. Keep that in mind when you are negotiating inspection items.
When a buyer signs a contract, the contract states:
‚ÄúBuyer agrees that minor repairs and routine maintenance items of the real estate do not constitute defects and are not a part of this contingency. The fact that a functioning major component may be at the end of its useful life shall not render such component defective for the purposes of this paragraph.‚Äù
If you‚Äôve signed this contract before, you might not have noticed that bolded section. Basically, that means if the property has a 20-year old furnace, you cannot ask for a new furnace. If the roof is at the end of its life but not leaking, you cannot ask for a new roof. It‚Äôs really important that you keep that in mind. You‚Äôll want to know how old the mechanicals are when you write the offer.
If you‚Äôre a seller and you know that your roof is at the end of its life, you may want to be proactive and get some estimates. That way, you‚Äôll know what the cost might actually be if you were to replace the roof.
Sometimes the buyer comes back with a laundry list of items that they want repaired. That list can turn a $500,000 deal into a disaster, and they may even end up canceling the deal because both parties get upset.
‚ÄúIf you are a buyer, you should only ask for major repair items, not a laundry list of small repairs.‚Äù
So, how can you prevent these issues from happening?
First, make sure you hire a real estate attorney. Not a corporate attorney or other kind of attorney‚Äîa real estate attorney. They are most familiar with the contracts that real estate agents use.
Next, have your expectations set by your Realtor. If you are the seller, make sure that everything is already out there. Notify the buyers that the roof is old before they write their offer. You don‚Äôt want them to be surprised by the inspection. If they know that the roof is 20 years old and they‚Äôll have to spend $10,000 to replace it in the next two years, that can really affect their purchase price or even their ability to buy the home.
You also need to look at the big picture. Are you ready to get this deal done? Is it important for you to secure this deal and not have to go back on the market? If you go back on the market after an inspection, you will have to disclose those items, which can make it more difficult to sell. It‚Äôs probably best to try and work with the buyer or seller to finish the deal.
If you are buying or selling a home, it‚Äôs really important for you to think about the inspection beforehand. Talk it out with your Realtor and figure out what to expect. If you are a buyer, don‚Äôt ask for a laundry list of repairs. Pick the main safety or health issues; those are the most important. If you are a seller, it‚Äôs important to realize that you can say no to what the buyer asks for. This is just another negotiation to work through.

item.title: How to Properly Price Your Home
item.author: Kati Spaniak
item.description:
If you‚Äôre planning on selling your home, you need to know how to price it correctly for the market.
Of course, you can use an automated valuation program like Zillow or on an agent‚Äôs website. Those work by pulling the data from the homes that have sold in the area. These automated valuations are hit and miss, however. It can be a good place to start.
If you‚Äôre planning on selling now, how do you know where your home sits in terms of value? First, let‚Äôs talk about the importance of pricing your home.
Pricing is the No. 1 most important thing when it comes to selling your house. There are a few misconceptions that people have when it comes to that.
When it comes to selling, your home is NOT worth:
What you paid for it What your neighbor says What you need What Zillow says What you want What it costs to rebuild today
The price of your home is actually what a buyer is willing to pay for it right now in this market.
More people come to view your home within the first three weeks of having it on the market. Those buyers who come in the first three weeks are looking with an agent, and ready to buy so you want your house to be priced correctly. After that, you‚Äôre riding the market down. Fewer people will come in after those three weeks if you‚Äôre not pricing it correctly. If you price it to high, they‚Äôll move on to another house completely or wait for your price to come down.
‚ÄúEven if the appraiser values your home at $500,000, if the market isn‚Äôt there, it might not actually sell for that much.‚Äù
Keep in mind, you can‚Äôt price it too low, either. You‚Äôll receive multiple offers that will push the price above your list value.
When it comes to finding the correct price, there are actually two values that I look at: appraised value and market value.
The appraised value is what you see on your computer or on paper. How many bedrooms do you have? What‚Äôs your square footage? How many bathrooms do you have? What year was it built? The answers to these questions will determine an appraiser‚Äôs valuation.
The market value is determined by the state of the current market. Even if the appraiser values your home at $500,000, if the market isn‚Äôt there, it might not actually sell for that much.
This is why you need to be talking to a real estate professional early on in the process, to make sure that the appraised value and the market value match up.
When you‚Äôre trying to figure out what the value of your home is, look first at:
Location. Are you near a school district? Compare your house only to those that are in your immediate area. Square footage. Is it the same as a house down the street? There are some tricks that people will use to increase the square footage, so you need to be aware of what the assessor says your square footage is. Remember that the assessment of your square footage is only going to include your first and second floors, not your basement. Condition. Make sure that the condition of your home matches the homes in your area. By ‚Äòcondition‚Äô, I mean something that‚Äôs been redone with the last five years. Comparables. You can only go off of what has sold in your area and not off of the active homes currently for sale. This is not a good comparable because you haven‚Äôt seen that a buyer is willing to pay that list price.
If you‚Äôre like to verify where your home is at in terms of value, feel free to reach out to me. I‚Äôd love to help you out.
